entity1.name: Tattoos
entity1.description: A form of body modification where designs are created by inserting ink into the skin.;;;A form of body modification where designs are created by inserting ink into the skin to change its pigment, often used in cultural contexts for symbolic or ritual purposes.;;;A traditional form of tattoo in Maori culture that signifies a person's lineage, tribal affiliations, and life story.;;;A form of body modification involving the creation of designs on the skin, often used for self-expression and identity formation.;;;A form of body modification involving the insertion of pigment into the skin to create designs, often used for protection and empowerment in various cultures.;;;A form of body modification involving the insertion of pigments into the skin to create designs, often used for personal and communal identity as well as in rituals and ceremonies.;;;Tattoos that commemorate significant personal milestones or transformations in one's life.;;;A form of body modification where designs are inked into the skin, often carrying symbolic or personal significance.;;;A form of body modification where designs are inked into the skin, often used to express personal or cultural identity.;;;A form of body art and self-expression that has been practiced for centuries, with varying cultural significance across different societies and time periods.;;;Permanent designs or marks made on the skin by injecting pigment into the dermis layer, often used for decorative, cultural, or symbolic purposes.;;;A form of body modification where designs are inked into the skin.;;;Tattoos created to honor and remember loved ones who have passed away.;;;A method of body modification where ink is inserted into the skin to create designs, often used for personal expression or cultural significance.;;;A form of body modification where designs are created by inserting ink into the skin to create permanent images or patterns, often used as a means of personal expression and identity.;;;Permanent designs made on the skin using needles to insert ink into the dermis layer.;;;A form of body modification where designs are inked into the skin, often used as symbols of identity, belonging, and ritual in various cultures.;;;A form of body modification where designs are inked into the skin, often used in cultural and personal rituals.

entity4.name: Polynesian cultures
entity4.description: A group of indigenous peoples and their associated cultural practices originating from the Polynesian islands in the Pacific Ocean.;;;Refers to the traditional and native societies that have historical continuity with pre-invasion or pre-colonial societies, often maintaining distinct social, cultural, and economic characteristics.
entity4.chunkid: The Cultural Significance of Tattoos6;;;The Cultural Significance of Tattoos14

entity6.name: Maori
entity6.description: The indigenous Polynesian people of New Zealand, known for their rich cultural heritage and traditions.

entity9.name: Western societies
entity9.description: Refers to the collective of countries and cultures primarily found in Europe, North America, and other regions influenced by Western traditions.

entity11.name: nature
entity11.description: The physical world, including plants, animals, landscapes, and natural phenomena.

entity12.name: mythology
entity12.description: A collection of traditional stories, often concerning gods, heroes, and supernatural beings, that explain aspects of the world or cultural beliefs.

entity16.name: Ainu
entity16.description: An indigenous ethnic group of Japan, known for their distinct culture and traditions.

entity17.name: Japan
entity17.description: A country located in East Asia, consisting of a large archipelago of islands in the Pacific Ocean.

entity19.name: community
entity19.description: A group of people who share common interests, values, or characteristics, often living in the same area or sharing a common culture.;;;A group of people living in the same area or having a particular characteristic in common, here referring to the social structure that supports and is supported by individuals with tattoos.
entity19.chunkid: The Cultural Significance of Tattoos19;;;The Cultural Significance of Tattoos16

entity20.name: natural world
entity20.description: The environment consisting of all living organisms and non-living elements occurring naturally on Earth, which individuals may feel a connection to through their cultural practices such as tattoos.

entity21.name: Samoan culture
entity21.description: The traditional practices and beliefs of the Samoan people, including social norms, customs, and rituals.

entity22.name: pe'a
entity22.description: A traditional Samoan tattoo that is a significant cultural symbol for young men, marking their transition into adulthood and commitment to the community.;;;A traditional Samoan tattoo that carries significant cultural and personal meaning, reflecting the wearer's family lineage, achievements, and personal values.
entity22.chunkid: The Cultural Significance of Tattoos18;;;The Cultural Significance of Tattoos17

entity25.name: cultural roots
entity25.description: The origins and traditions that define a person's heritage and background, connecting them to their ancestors and community.

entity28.name: Egypt
entity28.description: An ancient civilization and modern country in northeastern Africa, known for its historical monuments such as the pyramids and the Great Sphinx.

entity30.name: Japanese culture
entity30.description: The traditional practices, customs, and beliefs of Japan.

entity32.name: yakuza
entity32.description: A Japanese criminal organization known for its strict code of conduct and traditional practices, including the use of tattoos.;;;The yakuza, also known as Japanese mafia, is a collective term for organized crime syndicates in Japan.
entity32.chunkid: The Cultural Significance of Tattoos23;;;The Cultural Significance of Tattoos22

entity35.name: rituals and ceremonies
entity35.description: Structured activities or events with symbolic significance, performed on special occasions to mark important life transitions.
